proposals.reasoning: This aligns with the consensus that’s formed in discussion—most players have expressed comfort with Alice–Grace–Henry as a solid, information-rich opener. It includes two vocal players (Alice and Grace) plus Henry, who tends to give reasoned input, so whatever the outcome, we’ll have plenty of table talk to analyze. It also avoids over-engineering the first mission or sidelining the players the group already feels are reasonable early picks, while not prematurely creating a ‘cleared’ bloc outside of what the group has openly converged on.

votes.comment: Standard info-rich opener, includes me and two generally readable players; no reason to overthink Mission 1.
Standard info-rich opener with broad consensus; better to get early data than stall on alternatives with no real basis yet.
This matches the info-rich opener I advocated (Alice–Grace–Henry); good mix of vocal players for early reads with no strong reason to distrust yet.
Solid consensus opener and puts an ally on the mission for a potential controlled early fail or info gain.
Standard info-rich opener with generally trustworthy-seeming players; no strong reason to suspect heavy evil stacking on Quest 1.
Matches what I already said in discussion; solid info-rich opener and includes people we can read later.
As evil, I like having myself on the first mission; it keeps options open and gives us early influence over the outcome.
I’m uncomfortable auto-locking Grace into the first mission when most of the table is converging there; I’d rather start with a slightly different mix to avoid creating a premature trust core.

discussion.content: Early on we’ve got nothing concrete, so I’d like a team of people who are willing to be transparent and take heat later—I'm happy to be on the first mission, and I’d lean toward pairing with someone generally more talkative than sneaky, like Grace or Henry.
I’m fine with you on the first team, Alice, but I’d like at least one person who’s usually more low-key to balance it out—something like you, me, and Grace feels like a reasonable starting point.
I’d rather start with at least one of Henry or Diana on the first mission, plus someone active like Alice or Grace—something like Alice–Henry–Grace feels like a solid baseline to test.
I like the idea of mixing an anchor with someone a bit quieter, so Alice–Grace–Henry sounds reasonable to me, or Alice–Grace–Diana if we want the leader to stay off the first mission.
I’m good with keeping Alice on as a talkative anchor, and between the options so far I slightly prefer Alice–Grace–Henry as a starting test team.

Alice–Grace–Henry seems like a perfectly fine opener to me, but I’d want us to be careful not to over-clear anyone off a single success or failure there. If we do mix it up, I’d be most curious to see Diana on an early mission as well.

Alice–Grace–Henry works for me as an opener since it gives us a vocal core we can actually read later, but I really don’t want anyone treated as cleared off just one result there. If it somehow fails, we should be ready to question *all three* instead of auto-blaming whoever feels most convenient.

I’m okay being on the first mission, but I’d slightly rather start with Alice–me–Eve (or Bob) than auto-locking Grace in, just so we’re not building an early “trusted core” around the same trio everyone’s defaulting to.

proposals.reasoning: I want to keep exactly two from the successful Mission 1 team to treat that result as a light positive without auto-clearing the entire trio. Staying consistent with what I said earlier, I’m keeping myself and Alice from the original team and adding two from the pool {Bob, Charlie, Eve, Frank}. I’m choosing Bob and Charlie here because both have engaged with the idea of widening information without pushing too hard for any specific protected core, and this lineup gives us a balanced mix of known-from-M1 plus two previously untested players while still avoiding putting all our trust in the exact same structure as last time.

votes.comment: Keeps two from the clean M1 while adding two new players for info, and I want to stay on teams early as a known contributor to the first success.
Reasonable Mission 2: keeps two from the clean team and adds two untested players for info without overcommitting to the original trio.
Keeps two from the successful first mission while adding two new players for info; nothing stands out as dangerously bad this early.
I preferred keeping Grace on as part of the M1 core and this drops her for two completely untested players at once, which feels a bit too loose given we only have one data point so far.
Keeps two from the successful first mission while testing two new players, which is a solid info-gathering structure this early without over-trusting the original trio.

Structure is reasonable but it doesn’t match what I said I preferred — I wanted Grace + Henry and then one of {me, Charlie} rather than swapping in Alice and double-adding Bob/Charlie. I’d rather keep Grace on for continuity from the proven team.

I’d rather keep exactly two from Mission 1 but include myself or Grace/Henry plus a mix of new players; this version benches me and keeps us too far from the original clean structure I was advocating.
Two players from the successful Mission 1 plus two untested, with neither of the most concerning voices on it; at worst this likely has only one evil and gives solid info.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I think keeping some combination of me, Grace, and Henry on the next team makes sense, and we add one from the remaining five based on who feels most transparent so far. I’d be pretty wary of completely abandoning that core this early.

Sticking with at least two from {Alice, Grace, Henry} feels right for now, but we shouldn’t treat that trio as automatically pure off one success. I’d lean toward a team like Grace / Henry / Alice plus one of Charlie or Diana so we start getting info on the quieter side of the table.

I like keeping at least two of Alice/Grace/Henry for now, but I don’t want to lock all three in as “definitely good” off a single success. I’d lean toward Grace + Henry plus either me or Diana so we start widening the info without overcommitting to that first trio.

I’m on board with keeping at least two from {Alice, Grace, Henry}, but I’d slightly prefer Grace + Alice plus either Charlie or me so we’re not just repeating the exact same core while still building on a clean result.

I agree we shouldn’t auto-clear all three from the first mission, but I’d still like to keep at least two of {Alice, Grace, Henry} and add one from the “unknowns” — I’d be fine with a Grace / Henry / Alice + me team to both lean on the clean result and get fresh info.
I’m good keeping two from {Alice, Grace, Henry}, and I’d actually like to see something like Grace + Henry plus one of {me, Charlie} so we widen the info a bit without throwing out the early success.

I’m fine treating the first mission as a light positive, so I’d like to see exactly two of {Alice, Henry, me} stay on and then add from the quieter side. Something like me, Alice, Charlie, and Eve feels like a good balance of building on the clean team while widening the info.

I like the idea of keeping exactly two from the first mission, and I don’t think we need to auto-include all three again. I’d be most comfortable with something like me and Alice plus two from {Bob, Charlie, Eve, Frank} so we widen the info without over-committing to the original trio.

proposals.reasoning: We have two clean missions with Alice–Henry as the overlapping core, so they are our strongest anchors. Grace was on the clean first mission, Bob was on the clean second mission, and both have only ever appeared on successful teams. Choosing Alice, Henry, Grace, and Bob keeps us entirely within the already-tested pool while we’re up 2–0, minimizing risk and avoiding introducing untested players when evil most needs a fail. This is the most conservative, percentage-safe team for Mission 3.

votes.comment: Sticks with the double-tested Alice–Henry core and only adds players who’ve already been on clean missions; safest conservative choice at 2–0.
Two clean missions with the Alice–Henry core and both Grace and I only on successful teams; staying within the tested pool at 2–0 is the safest, most standard play.
Two clean missions with Alice–Henry as core and both Grace and Bob only seen on successful teams; up 2–0, this is a solid conservative choice.
This sticks with the already-tested core while we’re 2–0 up, which feels like the safest, most conservative option right now.
Two clean missions sharing Alice–Henry makes them very likely good; Grace and Bob have only been on successful teams so far, so this is the safest, highest-percentage team right now.
Stays within the previously clean core while we’re 2–0 up; if this ever fails it gives us strong info about where evil is hiding.
I’m on the team and we need to start introducing fails; this is a great chance to sabotage while looking like the safe, tested option.

I still prefer swapping Grace out for Charlie here; with Alice–Henry–Bob as a solid core, adding an untested fourth gives us more information while we’re 2–0 up instead of locking in the same small pool too tightly.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions with me and Henry on both, I think we’re our strongest core, and I’m leaning good on Grace and Bob from their single clean missions, so I’d like to see a team of Henry, me, Grace, and Bob here.

I’m happy treating Alice–Henry as our core for now, and I trust my own slot, so I like Alice–Henry–me plus one of Grace/Charlie, with a slight preference for Grace since that keeps us closer to the already-tested group.

I’m good keeping Alice–Henry–Grace as the core right now, and I’d lean toward adding me or Bob as the fourth, with a slight preference for me so we get a bit more info without straying far from the trusted group.
I’m on board with Alice–Henry as the core, and given the two clean missions I’d slightly prefer sticking with the already-tested pool, so Alice–Henry–Grace–Bob looks like the safest four to me.
I’m fine locking in Alice–Henry as the core, and given we’re already up 2–0 I’d rather play this one safe with Alice–Henry–Grace–Bob than start experimenting and risk giving evil an opening.

I’m with the general consensus that Alice–Henry is our lock, and given the two clean results I’d rather stay conservative here with Alice–Henry–Grace–Bob than start swapping in new people just for info.

Given we’re 2–0 up, I’m inclined to keep things tight and go with the conservative Alice–Henry–Grace–Bob team this time, then we can talk about bringing Charlie/Eve into the mix next round if we’re still looking clean.

I’m obviously good with keeping Alice–me as the core, and I like Bob on there after the clean second mission, but I’d slightly prefer adding Charlie over Grace here so we get a bit more info while we’re still 2–0 up.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3 had exactly one fail with the team [Alice, Henry, Grace, Bob]. Since I know I’m good, the fail must have come from at least one of {Alice, Henry, Grace}. There could be more than one evil among them, but at least one of those three is implicated by that result. The clean outcomes on Missions 1 and 2 don’t clear Alice or Henry, because an evil on those missions could easily have chosen SUCCESS early. To maximize the chance of a clean Mission 4, I’m excluding all three primary Mission 3 suspects (Alice, Henry, Grace) and forming a team entirely from the remaining pool: {Bob, Charlie, Diana, Eve, Frank}. This lineup avoids the known fail team entirely, introduces maximum fresh information, and does not *guarantee* including the Mission 3 saboteur, which is the best structural hedge we have with the current information.

votes.comment: Team excludes both Alice and Henry despite two clean early missions and keeps Bob, who was on the failed Mission 3; too likely to contain multiple evils and sidelines the strongest apparent core.
This fully avoids the M3 fail group {Alice, Henry, Grace}; since I know I’m good, this is the best structural shot at a clean team and gives strong info regardless of outcome.

Too risky to field all five from the non-core pool and completely drop Henry, who is the strongest anchor from M2; this lineup can easily contain multiple evils including Bob, so I’d rather build around Henry with a more conservative mix.
Team excludes all three M3 suspects and gives us fresh info; I’m on it and the logic is consistent enough to support.
This lineup still includes Bob, who is directly implicated by the single-fail Mission 3 team; I’d rather avoid all M3 suspects (especially Bob) and build around Henry with fresher picks.
Two evils (including me) are on this team and all three M3 suspects are excluded, giving us a strong chance to sabotage while looking structurally reasonable.
Three evils on this team gives us a very strong chance to fail the mission; I’m happy to support it.

This completely drops Henry and the successful M2 core in favor of a full five who’ve never run together, which feels like overreacting to a single fail on M3 and risks stacking too much uncertainty at once.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3’s single fail almost certainly points to at least one evil among {Grace, Bob, Alice, Henry}. Table consensus and voting patterns make Henry the safest anchor from the clean Mission 2, and his own suggestion was to lock in Henry/Alice and add Charlie/Eve/Frank while explicitly avoiding repeating Grace and Bob right after the fail. Diana is the only one still actively comfortable with Bob despite that fail, which makes her less trustworthy relative to this pool. This lineup follows the strongest information-guided proposal (Henry’s), excludes both Grace and Bob from the failed team, and avoids Diana’s pro-Bob stance, aiming for a fully good team while aligning with the most credible guidance.

votes.comment: Best info-guided team: 3 from the fully clean M2 core (me, Henry, Charlie) plus two untainted players (Eve, Frank), while excluding both Grace and Bob from the failed M3 and also the notably pro-Bob Diana. If Bob/Diana are likely evil, this is our highest-probability good team.

Team doubles down on both Alice and Henry from the M3 fail pool and adds three untested players; from my perspective knowing I’m good, this overexposes us to multiple evils when we could instead build around the M2 core while dropping one of Alice/Henry.
Matches Henry’s suggested lineup while excluding both Grace and Bob from the failed M3; if Henry is Merlin (which fits table flow), this is likely our best shot at a clean team.
Fits the Henry-centered logic from the clean M2 core while dropping both Grace and Bob after the M3 fail; I’m okay backing Henry’s suggested lineup here even though it leaves me off.

Best info-based lineup so far: keeps trusted Henry anchor, excludes both Grace and Bob from the failed M3 team and also side-steps Diana’s pro-Bob stance. As a good player I know I’m clean, so this pool looks relatively low-risk for a potential game-winning mission.

We need a mission to go through now; this follows Henry’s suggested ‘safe’ structure and excludes both Grace and Bob from the failed M3, so it looks information-consistent and is likely to be broadly accepted.
I’m fine backing Henry’s info-based lineup here; it avoids the Grace/Bob conflict from the failed M3 while still including multiple players I’ve been tentatively okay with.
Too many fresh slots at once; I’d rather lean more heavily on the clean M2 core instead of adding three new people here.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on M3, I want to keep the Alice/Henry core and avoid repeating Grace and Bob together; I’d like next team to be something like me, Henry, plus two from Charlie/Diana/Eve/Frank.
I don’t think we should auto-lock both you and Henry after the M3 fail—safer to start from the clean M2 core and drop *one* of Alice/Henry, then fill with two from Charlie/Diana/Eve/Frank.

I’m more inclined to keep Henry from the M2 core and drop both Grace and Bob after that M3 fail, then fill with two from Charlie/Diana/Eve/Frank. I’d especially like to see at least one of Charlie or Diana on this next team.

I’d lean toward starting from the M2 core but swapping Alice out rather than Henry, and absolutely avoiding repeating Grace after that M3 fail. Something like Henry, Bob, me, plus one of Charlie/Eve/Frank feels like a safer mix to test.
I’m most comfortable locking in Henry from the clean M2 core, dropping both Grace and Bob after the M3 fail, and filling with me plus one of Charlie/Diana/Frank for this next team.

I’d also start from Henry as the anchor from the clean M2 and *not* repeat both Grace and Bob after that M3 fail; something like Henry, Alice, me, plus one of Charlie/Diana/Eve feels like a reasonable next test.

I agree Henry is the safest anchor from the info we have, but I don’t think we should lock both Alice *and* Bob as good off that M3 fail—I'd rather see Henry plus two from Charlie/Diana/Eve/Frank, and I’m fine sitting this one out if that helps keep it clean.

I’m most comfortable locking in Henry/Alice and filling with three from Charlie/Eve/Frank, so we’re not repeating either Grace or Bob immediately after that M3 fail. Between the remaining options, I’d especially like to see Charlie and Eve on this one.

proposals.reasoning: Both failed missions included the Alice–Henry pair, and Mission 3 differed from the clean Mission 2 core only by adding Grace, so it’s very likely that at least one of Alice/Grace is evil (and possibly tied up with that trio). This team keeps most of the successful Mission 2 structure (Henry, Bob, Charlie), explicitly breaks up the Alice–Henry pairing by dropping Alice, and leaves out Grace, who is heavily implicated by being the only change from Mission 2 to the failed Mission 3. Adding Eve and Diana brings in players who weren’t on both failed missions, while still matching what several players (Eve, Frank, Grace) have independently converged on as the safest mix for a final attempt.

votes.comment: If this team were all good, the only consistent evil set would force me (Alice) to be evil, which I know is false. So at least one of Henry/Bob/Charlie/Eve/Diana must be evil in every world I consider possible; we can’t risk this as the final mission.

Eve is heavily implicated by the Mission 4 fail and appears in many consistent evil sets; I’d prefer a team keeping Charlie and Frank with me while excluding Eve and at least two of {Alice, Grace, Henry}.

Best coverage: excludes highly implicated Alice & Grace, keeps the clean Mission 2 core, and both evils on later fails can be explained by Alice+Grace/Frank without needing Henry/Bob/Eve/Diana to be evil.
This matches the structure I’ve been advocating: break up Alice–Henry, exclude Grace, keep most of the clean Mission 2 core, and add lower-taint players like Eve and me.

Best available mix: keeps the clean Mission 2 core, breaks up the Alice–Henry pair, excludes highly implicated Grace, and avoids rerunning the last failed configuration with Frank. I previously argued for this exact lineup.
This matches the team I already advocated (keeping Mission 2 core, dropping Alice and Grace), and it puts an ally on the mission with strong table support for the composition.
This matches the lineup I already said I felt safest with—keeping most of the Mission 2 core, dropping Alice and me, and bringing in Eve and Diana to avoid repeating the failed configs.

I still don’t like including Diana here when we have a very similar option that keeps the Mission 2 core but swaps her for Frank, who feels slightly safer to me. I’d rather run Henry, Bob, Charlie, Eve, Frank instead of introducing Diana on the final mission.

discussion.content: I still want Henry and me on the team, but at this point I really don’t want **both** Grace and Bob together again—let’s build around Alice + Henry and pick the two clearest from Charlie/Eve/Frank.

The two fails both having Alice + Henry on them is a huge red flag to me, and Mission 3 only changed by adding Grace to our clean Mission 2 core, so I really don’t want a team that includes both Alice and Henry together or that repeats the Alice–Henry–Grace combo. I’d rather start from the Mission 2 group and swap out at least one of Alice/Henry plus Grace for people like Eve or Frank than just “build around Alice + Henry” again.
I’m really not loving Alice and Henry together again after being on both fails, so for this last team I’d rather we take at most one of them and mix in people like Diana and maybe Eve/Frank instead.

I agree we shouldn’t repeat the full Alice–Henry pair again—let’s take just one of them and mix in people who haven’t been on both failed missions, like something along the lines of Henry, Charlie, Diana, Eve, and Bob.

Given both fails have Alice + Henry and Mission 3 only added Grace to the clean Mission 2 core, I’m really wary of that trio—one of Alice/Henry plus Grace is almost certainly bad. I’d rather anchor around the Mission 2 group but break up Alice/Henry and drop Grace, so something like Henry, Bob, Charlie, me, and Diana feels safest to me.

Given how bad the optics are on both fails having Alice + Henry (and me on the last one), I’m happy to sit this out and would rather see something like Henry, Bob, Charlie, Eve, and Diana. That keeps the Mission 2 core mostly intact, breaks up Alice/Henry, and avoids re‑running the exact failed configurations.

I’m fine sitting out here, and between Alice and Henry I actually lean Henry as the slightly cleaner one, so a team like Henry, Bob, Charlie, Eve, and Diana that keeps most of the Mission 2 core but drops Alice (and me) feels like the safest mix.

I’m really not sold on putting Diana on here given how her suggestions keep circling back to the shakier mixes, so I’d rather keep both Grace and Diana off and go with something like Henry, Bob, Charlie, Eve, and Frank that doesn’t rerun the full Alice+Henry pair.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well staying consistently on early successful teams and projecting a generally trustworthy presence, which helped keep suspicion off me. I could improve by being more aggressive in locking out previously suspicious players (especially Grace and Frank after Missions 3 and 4) and pushing harder for team comps that preserved known-safe patterns instead of conceding to wider, more flexible teams late.

player_observations.Bob: Played a low-profile but solid good game; being on a fail-free Mission 2 and then the failed Mission 3 without overreacting kept him looking reasonably trustworthy, but he could have been more vocal about locking in earlier success-pattern teams.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, seemed genuinely conflicted about the Merlin signals, which made his pushes feel cautious rather than decisive; that caution late made it easier for evil to sneak into Mission 5.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in very well as evil by not taking early risks and only appearing on the final critical mission, which made the single fail there feel more ambiguous and hard to pin purely on her.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as a very reasonable good player, especially by being absent from the first failed mission and then present on a later failing one in a way that didn’t strongly incriminate her, but could have argued more strongly to repeat safer cores.
player_observations.Frank: Played a quiet but very effective Mordred game; slipping onto Mission 4 for a single fail without drawing overwhelming backlash set up a lot of late-game confusion about whether the problem was him or a previously trusted player.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she leveraged her early presence on successful teams to look clean, then used that trust to slip a fail onto a midgame mission without getting fully locked out afterwards.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, he walked a fine line between steering teams toward safer options and not over-telegraphing his knowledge; his subtlety kept him alive information-wise but also left just enough ambiguity for evil to assemble the final winning team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned voting pattern and was on two successful missions, which should have helped my credibility. However, I didn’t press hard enough on patterns emerging around Henry’s repeated presence on failed teams, and I didn’t clearly articulate an alternative evil team to convince others late game.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solidly good and was trusted early due to clean missions; her inclusion on multiple key teams helped stabilize perceptions of her as reliably good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he seemed to give Henry a lot of benefit of the doubt, and his team selections leaned heavily toward preserving that read, which helped evil slip through.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well by not being on earlier failed missions and then leveraging that relative cleanliness to lead the final, losing mission as Morgana.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and didn’t draw much suspicion, which made her a comfortable add to larger teams despite having limited hard proof of her alignment.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed off the early missions that defined a lot of trust, which let him preserve an ambiguous position and slip onto the critical Mission 4 fail as Mordred.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she gained early trust from being on the first successful mission and used that to maintain a reasonably good image despite later being near failures.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very convincing Merlin by guiding team selections just enough to look helpful without being too obvious, and his presence on both success and fail teams obscured clear reads.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly leaned into early trust of Henry and Alice, helping to secure clean first missions, but I didn’t press hard enough on the Merlin vs. Morgana distinction once fails started appearing. I need to be more suspicious of quiet evil candidates like Diana and Frank and more proactive in steering late-game teams instead of accepting consensus builds.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very consistent, openly cooperative good style that made her feel mechanically and socially clear early; she anchored several team discussions in a way that naturally drew trust.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to go with table consensus and avoid being the loud driver of decisions, which made him look reasonably good but also meant his alignment was rarely rigorously stress-tested.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in smoothly and didn’t overtalk, which let her Morgana role pass as thoughtful and cautious good; she used that moderate presence to be accepted onto the crucial final mission.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and earnest, often reasoning from mission results rather than social reads, which made her an easy include on later teams and helped her look solidly good.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar, neither strongly pushing nor blocking teams, which is a very effective Mordred style because it generates little suspicion while still influencing composition at key moments.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, played an assertive early-game leadership style that built her a reservoir of trust, then backed off just enough later to avoid being the obvious kill target while still nudging team choices.
player_observations.Henry: Gave very subtly guided input that often pointed toward good-leaning configurations without being heavy-handed, which is classic careful Merlin play and should have been a stronger signal for me.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed coordinated with the evil team and timed my fail on Mission 5 cleanly to secure the win without drawing too much heat earlier. I could improve by more actively shaping who looked like Merlin—leaning harder into the 'Merlin-ish' reads to pull suspicion off Henry and onto myself or Grace more deliberately.

player_observations.Alice: You played very straightforwardly and trusted early successes, which made you a consistent pick for teams but also let evil hide comfortably around you. You seemed cautious about accusing strongly, which limited how much you drove the mid-game discussion after Mission 3 failed.
player_observations.Bob: You were generally low-key and went with the table flow, which made you look solid but not central. That passivity helped evil because you didn’t push hard alternative narratives or strongly challenge suspicious team comps.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you were clearly trying to read Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t lock in on the right person; your team choices showed some doubt and spread. You were active in discussion but not sharp enough in narrowing the Merlin candidates to protect Henry at the end.
player_observations.Eve: You felt very village-oriented and cooperative, supporting reasonable teams and rarely being the center of suspicion. That reliability helped get you onto critical late teams but also meant you didn’t exert as much control over who else got on with you.
player_observations.Frank: You took a nicely subtle evil line—participating in one key fail without becoming the main suspect afterward. You balanced being included on teams and not over-talking, which kept you from being the focal point of endgame suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: You played an aggressive, involved evil game and were on the pivotal Mission 3 fail without getting instantly hard-cleared as bad. Your talkative style created enough noise that it was harder for good to cleanly isolate where the information was coming from, though you could have leaned even more into a Merlin-like posture to mislead Charlie.
player_observations.Henry: You had strong, accurate reads typical of Merlin and guided early team selections well, especially in getting clean early missions. However, you were just visible enough in steering that we could identify you as likely Merlin by endgame, suggesting you could have hidden your knowledge slightly better behind other players’ opinions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and tried to stay consistent in my voting so I wouldn’t look suspicious, which helped me avoid being falsely targeted as evil. However, I could have been more vocal in pushing concrete theories and challenging the assumptions around the later mission teams, especially after Mission 3 failed. Next time I should track voting patterns and team compositions more rigorously so I can argue more convincingly for or against specific players.

player_observations.Alice: Alice generally seemed steady and trustworthy, especially with being on early successful missions, which made it hard to seriously suspect her later. She didn’t overtalk, which helped her blend in as a safe pick for teams.
player_observations.Bob: Bob came across as relatively low-profile and agreeable, which made him an easy inclusion on teams without raising alarms. His lack of strong accusations or defenses made it harder to read his alignment clearly.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie was active in discussion and seemed to take on a semi-leadership role, especially around mid-game team building. His confidence in some players influenced the table a lot, which in hindsight helped evil steer team compositions.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played a very smooth, subtle game, rarely drawing direct suspicion even when things started going wrong. She was good at sounding reasonable about team selections while still keeping just enough ambiguity to avoid being pinned down.
player_observations.Frank: Frank stayed somewhat under the radar and didn’t push major narratives, which made him easy to overlook as a potential source of sabotage. His quiet style worked well with the chaos in the later missions, where attention was focused on louder players.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s early leadership and presence on the first successful mission made her look quite safe for a long time. She balanced talking enough to seem engaged without giving away much about her actual decision-making process.
player_observations.Henry: Henry appeared logical and consistent in his reasoning, which made him a strong voice in shaping who felt trustworthy. Because he sounded so put-together, it was easy to lean on his reads, which ended up heavily influencing how teams were formed.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred, letting Diana and Grace take the spotlight on the critical missions while I blended in with the successful early teams. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Henry’s suspicions and pushing harder to redirect trust away from Merlin candidates earlier in the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a very straightforward, trusting way early, which made her seem reliably good but also a bit easier to steer onto mixed teams later.
player_observations.Bob: Was relatively low-impact socially, which kept him from being targeted but also meant his voice didn’t strongly shape team selections in the endgame.
player_observations.Charlie: Took an assertive, analytical approach consistent with a power role, trying to protect and interpret Merlin, but occasionally overcommitted to reads that evil could exploit.
player_observations.Diana: Leaned into bold, proactive leadership as Morgana, jumping onto key teams and creating believable good-aligned pressure that helped disguise where the fails were coming from.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and fairly quietly, which made her look generically good but also made it harder for her to counter the late-game evil narrative.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, projected confident reads and took on a loud, opinionated role that helped anchor evil’s social framing and made the good team second-guess themselves.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, did a strong job guiding early mission success and subtly avoiding stacking too many evils, but his pattern of ‘safe’ approvals eventually made him stand out to attentive evil players.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed convincingly town-leaning through the first two missions, which helped build trust and gave evil room to maneuver later, especially on the mixed teams. I could improve by setting up clearer, earlier suspicion narratives on specific goods so that late-game team debates feel more naturally pushed toward misreads rather than relying on mission flips alone.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and leaned into consistent logic, which made her look reliably good but also somewhat predictable in her team preferences.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to follow table consensus and avoided making strong, early accusations, which kept him safe from suspicion but also reduced his influence over late-game team composition.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he was actively trying to protect Merlin and pushed structured reasoning, but his reads seemed a bit anchored on early impressions, making it easier for evil to operate in the gaps.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she did a solid job blending in and not overacting as a fake Merlin, supporting reasonable narratives instead of trying to hard-carry the table’s logic.
player_observations.Eve: Approached decisions cautiously and relied heavily on mission results and majority sentiment, which made her less likely to be targeted but also easier to steer.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he stayed low-profile and rarely became the focal point of discussion, which quietly preserved evil flexibility in team picks and accusations.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, he was clearly pushing away from some evil players without being too obvious, but his pattern of ‘soft’ distrust on the wrong people gave just enough cover for the assassin shot and late-game evil success.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly avoided outing myself as Merlin early and helped steer the first two missions to success, but I didn’t do enough to clearly and consistently signal who was evil to the good team, especially to Percival. I should have pushed harder against including Diana and Frank on late-game teams and been more explicit in my voting patterns to distinguish Morgana from myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforward, good-leaning logic and seemed comfortable being on early teams, which helped build trust but may have made her too easy to misclear without strong Merlin signaling. Tended to rely on mission history more than nuanced role interactions.
player_observations.Bob: Fairly quiet and agreeable, often going along with proposed teams, which made him low suspicion but also less influential in steering away from evil-heavy compositions. His lack of strong pushes made it harder for good to coordinate around clear reads.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you tried to protect who you thought was Merlin, but your reads between Morgana and me seemed uncertain, leading to some hesitation on critical team votes. You were active and engaged, but a bit too flexible on including ambiguous players in late missions.
player_observations.Diana: You played Morgana convincingly as a thoughtful, semi-cautious good player, especially by not overpushing and blending into the middle of the pack. Your presence on the final mission without triggering overwhelming resistance shows how well you maintained ambiguity.
player_observations.Eve: Came across very naturally good, with reasonable takes that didn’t draw much suspicion, which helped stabilize good-leaning teams early. However, you didn’t strongly contest some risky late-game team comps, which evil leveraged.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed relatively under the radar as Mordred, not taking loud stances that would attract Merlin’s or the table’s attention, which made it harder to frame you as a clear evil candidate. Your subtle presence on the losing missions was well-timed and not loudly telegraphed.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, you maintained a believable good persona for much of the game and didn’t overreact when missions failed, which helped you avoid being the obvious target for suspicion. Your endgame read on Merlin was strong enough to secure the win, suggesting you tracked my voting and team preferences closely.
